 I have only read part of the replies on this board due to my time constraints but here is my stab at this. 
 
 The church was established by Jesus. Not necessarily a hierarchy of people. He confered leadership in a group he called elders. The conferred authority in a group called deacons. The reason for eldership was a plurality of leadership so that none would be more important than the others, so that the needs of people could be met through giving and so that people could be taught about the kingdom of God. The reason for the deacons is because the practical needs of the people became far too numerous for the elders to meet them. 
 
 Somewhere around the 3rd or fourth century the church started developing written doctrine and slowly moved leadership to a single person. The written doctrine was in response to a group of individuals that were teaching things then considered to be herasy. They felt the need to outline what was correct and what was not so as to know who to trust. There was a LOT of persecution of the early church (people thrown to lions, beheaded, etc for not worshipping Roman Gods). Who to trust was a crucial item.
 
 The singularity of leadership was so as to establish a final authority as to what was appropriate doctrine. This is where the church blew it in my mind. Jesus never intended his church to have a single person in authority. He conferred authority to a group. (this is my opinion and the roman catholic church has a different opinion).
 
 People meet in groups so as to understand and meet the needs of the group. The new testament clearly states that the members of the body were given different gifts for the purpose of meeting the needs of the body. They are clearly compared to a body where it says that a foot or hand or ear or eye are all part of one body and all are necessary.
 
 A side note, In earlier days, news was given so that the needs of people could be met. You received the news of things you could do something about (so and so's barn burneed last night, lets take over some clothes and food to help or help rebuild etc).
